newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia futures bourse chiefs support merger.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia futures bourse chiefs support merger.

text.p: The heads of futures exchanges the Malaysia Monetary Exchange and the Kuala Lumpur Options and Financial Futures Exchange said they supported a merger between them proposed by the Securities Commission.
They told Reuters Financial Television on Friday that the merger of MME, KLOFFE and the Kuala Lumpur Commodities Exchange (KLCE) would greatly enhance efficiency and reduce cost of operations.
A merger between the three was proposed by Munir Majid, chairman of the Securities Commission, this week.

"I think there are a number of compelling commercial issues that would mitigate in favour of some sort of merger (between) what are now three (futures) exchanges in Malaysia," said John Duggan, chief operating officer of KLOFFE.

KLOFFE trades futures on the Composite Index of blue chip stocks, MME trades an interest rate futures contract based on the benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) and KLCE has futures contracts in palm oil, rubber, tin and cocoa futures.
"I think if you just look at the issue of cost savings alone, there is tremendous duplication of effort," he told Reuters Financial Television's Asia Today programme.
He said among other areas that would benefit from a merger were development of new products, education and also market compliance and surveillance. Each exchange has its own programme in these areas.
Duggan said volumes on KLOFFE had risen sharply in the last two months to an average 1,300 contracts a day.
"At these sorts of turnovers, it points to about three billion ringgit worth of underlying activity a month," he said.
He said much of the volume came from Malaysian retail investors, while institutional investors were still reluctant to enter the market in a big way.

MME executive chairman Syed Jabbar Shahabuddin agreed with the view that merger of the three institutions would create a more cost-efficient futures exchange, but added that institutional reluctance to participate in trading was stunting volume growth.
"Local institutions are now gearing for participation," he told RFTV.
He said MME was planning to introduce new products such as a ringgit futures contract and a bond futures contract.

The introduction of new products and a tie-up with the New York Commodities Exchange, which allows the two to trade in each other's products, will enhance liquidity and popularity of derivatives as a price-hedging medium, he said.
